The keeper OF the Penitentiary in Geor-
gia, states in his annual report, that the In
sttution had betrayed ali its cxpences, and
had surplus of fifteen hundred and eighty
nine dollars and seventy mine cents. This
is the first year that clear profit has been
made upon the labour of the convicts, and
the only one in which no escapes have been
made.

News has been received at New-Yorli by /
The brig Laura, Captain Centre, from Cal 7
lao, very unfavorablc to the character Of
Bolivar. Capt. e. is said to bring ,nforma. !
ton which confirms, almost beyond doubt, \
the suspicious and report that Bolivar had
turned traitor to the cause OF liberty, and was
aiming at supreme power in the countries
he so largely contributed to liberate.
Capt Ccntre is likewise said to report
that about the 5th Sept. Bolivar declared
himself President Of Peru for life, with pow
or to appoint his successor. The Vice Pres
dent was also appointed for life and his old
est son to succeed him. Bolivar was ex-
ceeding!y unpopular at Lima, and the place
was in very unsettled state


III passing sentence, in the Court Of Oyer
and Terminer, in the city Of New York, OH
Tuesday week, upon the four citizens. Hen
ry B. Lambert, Samuel T. Lambert, Charles
Mowatt and Thomas Hyatt, convicted Of
fraudulent conduct in regard to some Of the
chartered monicd misunderstanding Ed
ward remarked -


"Eyen during the trials which have taken
place at the present term of this court, we
have witnessed displays of depravty OH the
part Of the agents of moneyed institutions
of the most appalling nature. AS common
as crimes are in all great cities, yet this
community was not prepared to expect from
the class Of society to which the perpctra-
tors Of these crimes belonged such burst
Of iniquity. These offences have been char
actcrised by the breaches OF official and per-
sonal confidence, by a course OF deception
and misrepresentation long and Systematically
pursued, and by injurious and crafty devices
which no ordinary prudence could guard a.
gainst. Nor was this all. Among the act
ors IN these scenes were some of the princi-
pai agents in the management of moneycd
institutions, and they have been found actu-
II ally combining and conspring together for
The accomplishment OF their neiarious pur-
II pcses.


From conspiraccs composed OF men OF
SO much talent, availing themselves OF their
Nlsh standing, it is not surprising that they

som OF ofdestruction. When crimes Of such a
character, attended with such destructive
consequences abound, it behoves the tribu-
hals OF justice to gather themselves up to
meet the occasion and to extend as far as
u'Asm lies, the protecting arm of the law

Gentlemen ofMc Scnote,


ind ofhe House Of Representatives:


IN closing my exercise OF the supreme exccu-
tive powers ofthe State, ! do not perceive the
necessity of recommending to your consider
alton any measures which have not been
submitted to you by myself or by my prede
cessors, or which the General Assembly has
not already had under its notice. This !
consider as a strong proof of the happy con-
diton OF our fellow citizens. We are in
more danger of suffering by innovations, than
from deficiency OF legislation. Our State
Constitution and the Constitution of the l.. I
States are sufficient to insure US all our rights 7
and privileges as people, and, as long as
they can be preserved to secure to ourselves
and 10 hand down to postcrity the bless |
ings Of liberty in all the purity of republic /
| cansm But the continued attempts made
to produce alterations in our primary insti-
tntions throughout the Union, fearfuly tore
bode, that the love of country, is becoming
a weak principle of action, and that selfish
ness SO powerfully enters into all the motives


lor seen novelties, that tic noble structure


which has been erected ''to form a more


perfect union, establish justice, ensure do


mcstc tranquility, provide for the common
defence, promote the general welfare, and
,ecnrc~ the blessings OF 'i]erty to ourselves


Nd our pos.crity," will be overwhelmed in
destruction, and that from lis ruins, will a


rS" liscord, the f0rrrunncr of slavery and


tyranny. Evils of this kind should be re-
sisted in their Origin, aud emphatcalv so


~ MS; for of all the States in the Union,


to none other j, it so prc-emnentlv import


ant that the General Government shonld be


preserved entire aad unimpaitcd Should
the Constitution of the United States be 50


patched aud altered that the warm attach


mtltEtw tttfor it BY the psop'e should
grow cold or even luEewarn, SO tina, il
Snail be injured by every uahcnlly at


tack, to what ark shall we iy for our tenn


poral safety and happnesss MY apprchen-


.ions are such that would not, had the
power, permit single Pin to he removed


from this sacred temple of liberty nor
would suffer any trappnEs 70 be added un-
der the prctcnce Of cmhelisiment or i'm
provumCnt, aud earnestly recommend to
Won, gentlemen, not to listen with favor to


any propositions Of the kind.


Another subject, often repeated, but still


not thc less Important, j., 81 sorcbly impress


ed on ny mind that Win not out this last


opportunity Of urging it upon your consid


Grafton. ! refer Ia education, ,-not to the


mere acquisition of the arts Of reading aud
e,
and of foreign and dead langnagcs--but to
the formation Ht the manners and minds OF


youth and to the observance of moral du-


ties. The discipline Of the mind, the re-


s,tauce and correction OF the evil propens


itics Of our nature, the restraining and Keep


ingiwithin boulids our unlawful appetites; the


cultivation OF bcncvolcucc 70 man and love t.
: oar Creator, should be the first and constant
h lesson taught to youth rs well to promote


their own individual happiness as to endear


to them their country, and make them in-


corruptibic patriots. SO powerful was the
. effect of education among the I.accdemoui-
c ans, that, although beaten in battle, they
=, could not be conquered until their mannc,
of educating their children WAS changed
Education must depend upc~ the public insti
Q tutions, and such as aft CT parents; and as soot
&c soon as they set the example and instil int
4 the children proper principles, the chiidrei
;, will become good and virtnous citizens, ant


their ruling passion viii he the love OF thei
e country. The learning to he gained in schools
IL is a secondary ubcct--usciul in proportion t
i the subjcction of the passions, and calcnlat
ed to einbelish the virtues of a well regu
lated mind, or to enlarge and stimulate th'
! deptavity Of a corrupt heart.

A writcrat Berlin, in q letter to his friend in
speaking Of young Napoleon says


':At Vienna saw the Imperial family at the
Opera; and among them the Empress Maria Lou
is., and her son, the yonng Napoleon. had my
eye fixed upon the latter Tor more than two
hours, rctracing in my mind the eNentinl life OF
his sire, 10 whom he has great resemblance -
The general turn of the head, thc orehcad, the
eyes and the superior part Of his nose, arc all his.
There is great deal Of expression in The boys
features; lie was deeply Interested by the play.
and contrary TO every etiquette Of 50 rigid court
as that to which lie is attached, made no at
tempt to conceal his cmot;c 5: his mother re-
pca,edly checked him, hut 10 little purpose He
isa kind Of spoiled child Of his grandi. thcr.

, Before bid you adiet, must beg YOU. gen.

arising from intention, or from any evil motives.

News has been received at New-Yorli by /
The brig Laura, Captain Centre, from Cal 7
lao, very unfavorablc to the character Of
Bolivar. Capt. e. is said to bring ,nforma. !
ton which confirms, almost beyond doubt, \
the suspicious and report that Bolivar had
turned traitor to the cause OF liberty, and was
aiming at supreme power in the countries
he so largely contributed to liberate.
Capt Ccntre is likewise said to report
that about the 5th Sept. Bolivar declared
himself President Of Peru for life, with pow
or to appoint his successor. The Vice Pres
dent was also appointed for life and his old
est son to succeed him. Bolivar was ex-
ceeding!y unpopular at Lima, and the place
was in very unsettled state


III passing sentence, in the Court Of Oyer
and Terminer, in the city Of New York, OH
Tuesday week, upon the four citizens. Hen
ry B. Lambert, Samuel T. Lambert, Charles
Mowatt and Thomas Hyatt, convicted Of
fraudulent conduct in regard to some Of the
chartered monicd misunderstanding Ed
ward remarked -


"Eyen during the trials which have taken
place at the present term of this court, we
have witnessed displays of depravty OH the
part Of the agents of moneyed institutions
of the most appalling nature. AS common
as crimes are in all great cities, yet this
community was not prepared to expect from
the class Of society to which the perpctra-
tors Of these crimes belonged such burst
Of iniquity. These offences have been char
actcrised by the breaches OF official and per-
sonal confidence, by a course OF deception
and misrepresentation long and Systematically
pursued, and by injurious and crafty devices
which no ordinary prudence could guard a.
gainst. Nor was this all. Among the act
ors IN these scenes were some of the princi-
pai agents in the management of moneycd
institutions, and they have been found actu-
II ally combining and conspring together for
The accomplishment OF their neiarious pur-
II pcses.


From conspiraccs composed OF men OF
SO much talent, availing themselves OF their
Nlsh standing, it is not surprising that they
Moulu have swept society as with the be
som OF ofdestruction. When crimes Of such a
character, attended with such destructive
consequences abound, it behoves the tribu-
hals OF justice to gather themselves up to
meet the occasion and to extend as far as
u'Asm lies, the protecting arm of the law





IN contemplating your cases we have
considered your former standing in society;
let can perceive in it nothing to entitle you
70 our ciemency. The miserable sons and
uauShters ot vice may plead their ignorance
anu their necessities, and to such an effect
as 10 draw tears from the eyes CT justice
she she strikcs.--But your talent and sta
u'n IN society afforded You commanding
view view OF your duty, and put in your power tt
o5'ah ny honest means respectable sup
po't II your punishment were to be meas
u'eu by the suticrings you have produced
would be difficult to fix limits to it. If we
sls'Suer your punishment with a view t
t. ."e character of the offence, the stern die
,'es OF justice forbid that we should falter
WIN :. WIN q view to the future state oftsocicty
vnp vHpr'iehce raises her monitpry voice agains
,;s nut although nothing can be said in jus
ya,.,' "'ol " or excuse for your conduct, ye
trO0;. @a onehces are far from being equally at

full articles.headline:
MESSAGE

ofthe Governor Of Deia7carc TO The Gene


at assembly,
full articles.article:
Gentlemen ofMc Scnote,


ind ofhe House Of Representatives:


IN closing my exercise OF the supreme exccu-
tive powers ofthe State, ! do not perceive the
necessity of recommending to your consider
alton any measures which have not been
submitted to you by myself or by my prede
cessors, or which the General Assembly has
not already had under its notice. This !
consider as a strong proof of the happy con-
diton OF our fellow citizens. We are in
more danger of suffering by innovations, than
from deficiency OF legislation. Our State
Constitution and the Constitution of the l.. I
States are sufficient to insure US all our rights 7
and privileges as people, and, as long as
they can be preserved to secure to ourselves
and 10 hand down to postcrity the bless |
ings Of liberty in all the purity of republic /
| cansm But the continued attempts made
to produce alterations in our primary insti-
tntions throughout the Union, fearfuly tore
bode, that the love of country, is becoming
a weak principle of action, and that selfish
ness SO powerfully enters into all the motives


lor seen novelties, that tic noble structure


which has been erected ''to form a more


perfect union, establish justice, ensure do


mcstc tranquility, provide for the common
defence, promote the general welfare, and
,ecnrc~ the blessings OF 'i]erty to ourselves


Nd our pos.crity," will be overwhelmed in
destruction, and that from lis ruins, will a


rS" liscord, the f0rrrunncr of slavery and


tyranny. Evils of this kind should be re-
sisted in their Origin, aud emphatcalv so


~ MS; for of all the States in the Union,


to none other j, it so prc-emnentlv import


ant that the General Government shonld be


preserved entire aad unimpaitcd Should
the Constitution of the United States be 50


patched aud altered that the warm attach


mtltEtw tttfor it BY the psop'e should
grow cold or even luEewarn, SO tina, il
Snail be injured by every uahcnlly at


tack, to what ark shall we iy for our tenn


poral safety and happnesss MY apprchen-


.ions are such that would not, had the
power, permit single Pin to he removed


from this sacred temple of liberty nor
would suffer any trappnEs 70 be added un-
der the prctcnce Of cmhelisiment or i'm
provumCnt, aud earnestly recommend to
Won, gentlemen, not to listen with favor to


any propositions Of the kind.


Another subject, often repeated, but still


not thc less Important, j., 81 sorcbly impress


ed on ny mind that Win not out this last


opportunity Of urging it upon your consid


Grafton. ! refer Ia education, ,-not to the


mere acquisition of the arts Of reading aud
e,
and of foreign and dead langnagcs--but to
the formation Ht the manners and minds OF


youth and to the observance of moral du-


ties. The discipline Of the mind, the re-


s,tauce and correction OF the evil propens


itics Of our nature, the restraining and Keep


ingiwithin boulids our unlawful appetites; the


cultivation OF bcncvolcucc 70 man and love t.
: oar Creator, should be the first and constant
h lesson taught to youth rs well to promote


their own individual happiness as to endear


to them their country, and make them in-


corruptibic patriots. SO powerful was the
. effect of education among the I.accdemoui-
c ans, that, although beaten in battle, they
=, could not be conquered until their mannc,
of educating their children WAS changed
Education must depend upc~ the public insti
Q tutions, and such as aft CT parents; and as soot
&c soon as they set the example and instil int
4 the children proper principles, the chiidrei
;, will become good and virtnous citizens, ant


their ruling passion viii he the love OF thei
e country. The learning to he gained in schools
IL is a secondary ubcct--usciul in proportion t
i the subjcction of the passions, and calcnlat
ed to einbelish the virtues of a well regu
lated mind, or to enlarge and stimulate th'
! deptavity Of a corrupt heart.

Nv last say in the Nilmingtonian CON
Guided with all idea that the quails which
descended for the noulishment Of the chill
drcn of Israel had been raincd alive, two Gu
bits; upwards Of three feet, il height from
the ground. On a retrospective view of the
subject, it appears most reasonable that they
were not in state Of animation at the time
of their descent: consequently required no
sustenancc from the ground, 10 suppose
otherwise would be to suppose them TO have
scattered far and wide, which is rather an
infringement upon the space witch we
must necessarily allot for tie district upon
which the mama, likewise had fallen. Let
US suppose that the encampment in and a
bout which the quails were distributed, a
mounted to fifteen hundred acres; outside
of which may be considered the mama
ground: now, as every one gathered an omcr
per day, let us suppose that off every square
perch of ground an omer was gathered: the
soil necessary to contain this mama amounts
to about one million of perchts, or 6250 a
crcs Of land, so that rali drawn from the
centre of said encampment to the boundary
line would he sufficient journey to SO and
return in &C space of half day with then
loads. An omer is reckoned about six pnts
Ten omers and about six-tenths is bushcl
consequently, the amount daily gathered was
"a, ,358 bushels.

A writcrat Berlin, in q letter to his friend in
speaking Of young Napoleon says


':At Vienna saw the Imperial family at the
Opera; and among them the Empress Maria Lou
is., and her son, the yonng Napoleon. had my
eye fixed upon the latter Tor more than two
hours, rctracing in my mind the eNentinl life OF
his sire, 10 whom he has great resemblance -
The general turn of the head, thc orehcad, the
eyes and the superior part Of his nose, arc all his.
There is great deal Of expression in The boys
features; lie was deeply Interested by the play.
and contrary TO every etiquette Of 50 rigid court
as that to which lie is attached, made no at
tempt to conceal his cmot;c 5: his mother re-
pca,edly checked him, hut 10 little purpose He
isa kind Of spoiled child Of his grandi. thcr.
